case_data.name: Dodge v. Orange County
case_data.plaintiff_description: All pre-trial detainees placed in custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office on or after 1/31/99 and strip-searched upon their arrival at the Orange County Jail pursuant to dfts' uniform strip-search.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On January 31, 2002, three plaintiffs represented by private New York-based attorneys filed a class action civil rights lawsuit pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. They alleged that the Orange County Sheriff's Department had an unconstitutional blanket policy and/or practice of strip searching all individuals who entered the Orange County Correctional Facility (jail), including those charged with misdemeanors or held on civil matters, regardless of the crime for which they were charged and without reasonable suspicion to believe that the individuals were concealing weapons or contraband. Under the policy, each detainee was allegedly forced to strip naked, bend over and/or squat, lift his/her genitals and spread the cheeks of his/her buttocks so that jail guards could complete a visual search of his/her body. Plaintiffs alleged that the policy violated the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution. They sought a preliminary and permanent injunction, monetary damages, and class certification.

Defendants, the County and the Sheriff, answered by generally denying all allegations. Defendants also moved to dismiss the request for injunctive relief on standing grounds, as a new strip search policy was adopted at the jail in August 2001. The District Court (District Judge Colleen McMahon) denied the motion to dismiss and ordered a full evidentiary hearing. Dodge v. County of Orange, 208 F.R.D. 79 (S.D. N.Y. 2002). Following a hearing on June 24, 2002, the District Court granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification and issued a preliminary injunction. The injunction allowed defendants to conduct strip searches of newly-arrived inmates only when they had reason to believe the new arrival might be secreting contraband, based on (1) the nature of the crime charged; (2) the circumstances of the arrest; and (3) the particular characteristics of the arrestee. Dodge v. County of Orange, 209 F.R.D. 65 (S.D. N.Y. 2002). Judge McMahon ordered that the case proceed in two phases: (1) trial on liability (whether the policy was unconstitutional and whether a permanent injunction should be issued) and (2) damages.

On October 22, 2002, a second complaint, Rango v. County of Orange, 02 Civ. 8451 (S.D. N.Y. 2002) (" Rango ") was filed. The Rango plaintiffs purported to represent a class of pre-trial detainees charged with felonies who were admitted to the Orange County Correctional Facility ("OCCF") from January 1, 1999, to the present and allegedly strip searched in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution. The Rango plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction soon after filing their complaint.

The Court consolidated the Dodge and Rango cases so that a single trial could be conducted on plaintiffs' requests for permanent injunctive relief in both cases. The consolidated trial was conducted over four days, between May 19 and May 28, 2003.

The Court found that the strip search policy violated the Fourth Amendment to extent that it allowed strip searches without individualized reasonable suspicion. Judge McMahon issued a permanent injunction against unconstitutional aspects of the county jail's policy. Dodge v. County of Orange, 282 F. Supp.2d 41 (S.D. N.Y. 2003). Orange County appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeal was dismissed in a summary decision later amended by the court, and the case remanded to the District Court for a determination as to whether plaintiffs had standing (e.g., a likelihood of future harm from the wrongful official policy) to pursue injunctive relief. Dodge v. County of Orange, 99 Fed. Appx. 347 (2nd Cir. 2004), opinion amended and superseded by Dodge v. County of Orange, 103 Fed. Appx. 688 (2nd Cir. 2004).

On remand, plaintiffs withdrew their claim for injunctive relief. They sought decertification of the injunctive class and certification of a class, or classes, of plaintiffs for purposes of recovering damages. Defendants opposed the new damages class request. Judge McMahon bifurcated the liability and damages phases of the cases and certified the classes only on the issue of liability - the constitutionality of the strip search policy. Dodge v. County of Orange, 226 F.R.D. 177 (S.D. N.Y. 2005). Following certification, settlement negotiations ensued and the parties entered into a proposed Settlement Agreement.

Under the Settlement Agreement, Orange County agreed to pay $624,800 into a fund for payment of class claims. Of that amount, $10,000 was to be divided among the class representatives. Eligible felony detainees were to receive $100.00 each. Eligible non-felony detainees were to receive $1,000, unless they met certain reduction criteria, in which case they would receive $250. The County also agreed to pay class counsel attorneys' fees in the amount of $600,000.

On March 2, 2006, the Court preliminarily approved the Settlement Agreement and set the matter for a fairness hearing on June 9, 2006. Final approval was granted for the settlement by Judge McMahon on June 26, 2006.

We have no information that post-settlement activity occurred in the case.

Footnotes 
 
1  Plaintiffs originally sought to represent classes of misdemeanor and felony detainees, respectively, from January 31, 
  1999 through the date of judgment. They have narrowed the class period, apparently in view of certain findings this 
court made at the trial of their action for preliminary and permanent injunctive relief. Dodge v. County of Orange, 
282 F.Supp.2d 41, 85โ86 (S.D.N.Y.2003). Those findings are not binding on anyone any more, in view of the Second 
Circuitโs vacatur of that decision, but plaintiffsโ counsel appears to have given up the contention that all pre-trial 
detainees who arrived at OCCF after August 6, 2002 were strip searched pursuant to a uniform policy. 
 
2  Shain v. Ellison, 273 F.3d 56 (2d Cir.2001)(โShain Iโ); Wachtler v. County of Herkimer, 35 F.3d 77 (2d Cir.1994); Walsh 
  v. Franco, 849 F.2d 66 (2d Cir.1988); Weber v. Dell, 804 F.2d 796 (2d Cir.1986). I will frequently refer to these four 
cases together as โWeber/Walsh/Wachtler/Shain I.โ 
 
3  Plaintiffs allege that this Courtโs decision in Murcia put the County defendants on notice, as of the date of that 
  decision, that the indiscriminate strip searching of newly-arrived felony detainees was unlawful, and that the law, 
for qualified immunity purposes, was โclearly established.โ However, the Second Circuit has held that the law 
cannot be โclearly establishedโ for qualified immunity purposes by district court opinions, but only by the decisions 
of the applicable circuit court or the Supreme Court. Shechter v. Comptroller of New York, 79 F.3d 265, 271 (2d 
Cir.1996); Jermosen v. Smith, 945 F.2d 547, 550 (2d Cir.1991); Hawkins v. Steingut, 829 F.2d 317, 321 (2d Cir.1987); 
Chipperini v. Crandall, 253 F.Supp.2d 301, 307 (D.Conn.2003). 
 
4  I recognize that Judge Hurley has, on multiple occasions, both before and after Visa Check was decided, refused to 
  certify a class in a similar case pending in the Eastern District, Augustin v. Jablonsky, 99 Civ. 3126(DRH), 2001 WL 
770839 (E.D.N.Y.2001), on the ground that common issues did not predominate. I am not familiar with the record in 
7 
 

 
 
Dodge v. County of Orange, 226 F.R.D. 177 (2005)   
 
 
Augustin; perhaps I would have reached the same result on the record before Judge Hurley. Even the same court 
can reach different conclusions in different cases; for example, I am today declining to certify classes in a companion 
case involving the strip search policies at the Dutchess County Jail because, on a rather different fact pattern, 
common questions do not predominate. See Franklin v. County of Dutchess, No. 03 Civ. 719(CM), 225 F.R.D. 487 
(S.D.N.Y.2005). But on the record before meโa record I know wellโI do not find the reasoning of Augustin 
persuasive in view of Visa Check and Robinson, supra, and I respectfully decline to follow it. 
 
5  The principal reason why defendants wanted to have a quick trial on the merits of plaintiffsโ application for 
  permanent injunctive relief was so that, if the Second Circuit reversed itself (or the Supreme Court reversed the 
Second Circuit) in Shain v. Ellison, the jail could โrevertโ to the policy of strip searching every new arrival, regardless 
of his individualized circumstances. OCCF officials were eager to strip search every new arrival for what they claimed 
were security reasons. See Trial Transcript, Testimony of Captain Joseph G. Ryan, at 106โ07; 115โ16. It will be 
difficult if not impossible for the County to retreat from its prior position on the existence of a uniform strip search 
policy at the โoldโ OCCF, even though the findings made after the Dodge trial are no longer binding. 
 
6  As a purely practical matter, I must observe that, if thousands of individual plaintiffs brought individual actions in 
  this court ab initio, those actions would likely be assigned to me as โrelated cases,โ and I would consolidate them for 
the purpose of determining liability. 
 
7  I recognize that I cannot resolve merits issues as part of a decision on a motion for summary judgment. However, 
  this case carries a lot of โmeritsโ history. Plaintiffs have already announced that they intend to move for summary 
judgment on the โexistence of a policyโ issue. Given the facts known to this court, it would be foolish not to 
acknowledge that plaintiff might well prevail on such a motion for the pre-August 2001 periodโeven if Lee does not 
collaterally estop the County and Bigger from relitigating the issue. Defendants could just as easily have prevailed on 
such a motion for the period from and after August 2002 had plaintiffs not withdrawn their proposal to certify a 
class for that period. 
I imagine that the parties will move for cross-motion for summary judgment on the existence of a policy issue for 
the year between August 2001 and August 2002. I cannot stop anyone from making such a motion, but let me 
suggest that summary judgment will not be an appropriate vehicle for resolving the question. In this regard, I 
remind the parties that Dodge I findings concerning the interim year were not based on undisputed facts. Many 
facts concerning the existence or non-existence of a policy from August 2001โAugust 2002 were in dispute, and I 
resolved them by making, inter alia, credibility findings. Now that we are dealing only with an action for damages, 
I will not be the fact-finder and I would not be in a position to make credibility assessments or resolve evidentiary 
conflicts should they emerge from the record on a motion for summary judgment. If the record on such a motion 
is no different from the trial record, there is no question that there will be disputed issues of fact, which will be 
tried to a jury. Moreover, that jury will not be made aware of how the court ruled on those same issues after the 
first trial. 
 
8  In what the court interprets as an attempt to intimidate me from concluding that there are ways to manage 
  issue-oriented class certification, the County has intimated that it would not consent to have damages inquests for 
class members held before one of our excellent magistrate judges. That, of course, is the Countyโs right. Fortunately, 
there are many other ways of handling such matters. For example, if the Countyโs liability were established because 
8 
 

 
 
Dodge v. County of Orange, 226 F.R.D. 177 (2005)   
 
 
the trier of fact concluded that a uniform policy existed, I could appoint an out-of-district Article III judge whose 
docket is not overcrowded to serve as a special master. That judge could then travel to New Yorkโat the 
defendantsโ expense, of courseโto supervise the damages trials. 
 
9  The fact that the parties treated these two periods differently during the Dodge I trial is a persuasive reason for 
  dividing the classes in this fashion.

documents.title: Class Action Complaint Jury Demand
documents.text:
2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 1
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
For Opinion See 226 F.R.D. 177, 282 F.Supp.2d 41, 209 F.R.D. 65, 208 F.R.D. 79
United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Anthony DODGE, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Petriello, individually and on behalf of
all others similarly situated, Plaintiff,
v.
COUNTY OF ORANGE and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, in his individual and official capa-
city, Defendants.
No. 2002-9006.
January 29, 2002.
Class Action Complaint Jury Demand
Plaintiffs, Anthony Dodge, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Petriello, individually and
on behalf of all others similarly situated, by and through their attorneys, Dupee,
Dupee & Monroe, P.C., as and for their Complaint, upon information and belief, state
as follows:
INTRODUCTION
FIRST: This is a civil rights action brought pursuant to the United States Constitu-
tion as amended, and 42 U.S.C. ยง1983 seeking redress for defendants' deprivation,
under Color of State Law. of plaintiffs' rights, privileges, and immunities secured
by the Constitution and Laws of the United States.
SECOND: At all times hereinafter mentioned, the defendants instituted and affirmed a
policy, practice, procedure and custom pursuant to which strip searches of all pre-
trial detainees held in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office are con-
ducted in the absence of reasonable suspicion as otherwise required and prescribed
by the Constitution and Laws of the United States and the State of New York. This
uniform policy, practice, procedure and custom of strip searching all pre-trial de-
tainees held in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office, including the
named plaintiffs and those similarly situated, without particularized suspicion
borne of the facts of an individual case, was humiliating, unduly invasive, uncon-
stitutional and prohibited by Civil Law of the United States and the State of New
York
THIRD: The plaintiffs' class seek (i) a declaratory judgment declaring that a strip
search of a pre-trial detainee undertaken in the absence of reasonable suspicion
that the detainee is concealing weapons or other contraband constitutes an unreason-
able search and is unconstitutional; (ii) an order enjoining defendants from imple-
menting or enforcing their policy, practice, procedure and custom of conducting
strip-searches of pre-trial detainees in the absence of reasonable suspicion to jus-
tify the search; (iii) compensatory damages for the injuries caused by defendants'
unlawful conduct; and (iv) punitive damages assessed against the individual defend-
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 2
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
ant to deter such intentional, reckless and unlawful disregard for the well-settled
constitutional law of the United States and the State of New York.
JURISDICTION AND VENUE
FOURTH: This action arises underthe Fourth, Fifth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments
to the United States Constitution and 42 U.S.C. ยง1983.
FIFTH: The jurisdiction of this Court is predicated upon 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331, 1343(4),
1367(a) and 2201.
SIXTH: Venue lies with the United States District Court for the Southern District of
New York pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง1391(b).
JURY DEMAND
SEVENTH: Plaintiffs demand trial by jury of all issues in this action.
NAMED PARTIES
EIGHTH: Anthony Dodge is a named representative of this proposed class action. Mr.
Dodge is 36 years old and resides in the County of Orange, State of New York. He was
arrested on or about April 28, 1999 and charged with one count of disorderly conduct
(a violation). After Mr. Dodge was arraigned by the City of Port Jervis City Court
he was placed in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office.
NINTH: Peter A. Machado is a named representative of this proposed class action. Mr.
Machado is 19 years old and resides in the County of Orange, State of New York. He
was arrested on August 17, 1999 and charged with one count of petit larceny (a Class
โAโ misdemeanor); and unlawful possession of an alcoholic beverage under the age of
21 (a violation). After Mr. Machado was arraigned by the City of Port Jervis City
Court, he was placed in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office.
TENTH: Joseph M. Petriello is a named representative of this proposed class action.
Mr. Petriello is 26 years old and resides in the County of Orange, State of New
York. He was arrested on December 2, 2001 and charged with driving while intoxicated
(a Class โEโ felony) together with several vehicle and traffic law infractions.
After Mr. Petriello was arraigned by the Town of Monroe Justice Court, he was placed
in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office.
ELEVENTH: Upon being placed in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office,
each of the above named plaintiffs was strip searched, without inquiry into the
nature of the charges, the characteristics of the arrestee, or the circumstances of
the arrest and without establishment of reasonable suspicion to believe that any of
the above named plaintiffs was armed, dangerous or possessed weapons or contraband
of any kind in accordance with the policy, custom, procedure and practice of the de-
fendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger.
DEFENDANTS
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 3
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
TWELFTH: Defendant, County of Orange, is a municipal organization existing under and
by virtue of the laws of the State of New York, and is responsible for the policy,
practice, procedure, supervision, implementation and conduct of all Orange County
Sheriff's Office matters.
THIRTEENTH: That all times hereinafter mentioned, the Orange County Sheriff's Office
is an administrative arm and/or subdivision of the County of Orange and was at all
times under the direction and control of the defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger.
FOUTEENTH: That at all relevant times hereinafter mentioned, defendants, County of
Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger,and each of them, were responsible for the
policy, practice, supervision, implementation and conduct of all Orange County Sher-
iff's Office matters and was and are responsible for the appointment, training, su-
pervision and conduct of all Orange County Sheriff's Office personnel.
FIFTEENTH: Defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, is the duly elected Sheriff of the
County of Orange pursuant to Article XVII of the Orange County Charter, and in that
capacity has the power and the duties as provided by ยง 17.02 of the Orange County
Charter and as otherwise provided by law. Defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, is
sued in his individual and official capacity as Sheriff of the County of Orange.
SIXTEENTH: At all times hereinafter mentioned, and in all of his actions described
herein, defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, was acting under Color of Law pursuant
to his authority as Sheriff of the County of Orange.
SEVENTEENTH: The Orange County Sheriff's Office, is an agency and/or subdivision of
the defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger who are responsible for
overseeing, organizing, administrating and implementing a county jail in which,
among other things, pre-trial detainees are incarcerated. At all times hereinafter
mentioned, defendant, County of Orange, together with Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, are
and were responsible for the policy, practice, supervision, implementation and con-
duct of all Orange County Sheriff's Office matters and were responsible for the ap-
pointment, training, supervision and conduct of all Orange County Sheriff's Office
personnel. In addition, and at all times hereinafter mentioned, defendant, County of
Orange, together with Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, were responsible for enforcing the
rules and regulations of the Orange County Sheriff's Office, and for ensuring that
the Orange County Sheriff Office's personnel obeyed the United States Constitution,
the laws of the United States and of the State of New York.
EIGHTEENTH: The Orange County Sheriff's Office is the agency of the county respons-
ible for, among other functions, maintaining custody over pre-trial detainees.
NINETEENTH: Defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, is the Sheriff for the Orange County
Sheriff's Office, and as such, is the policy-maker with respect to the treatment and
processing of all pre-trial detainees who have been or are in the custody of the Or-
ange County Sheriff's office. The principal place of business of the Orange County
Sheriff is located at 110 Wells Farm Rd., Goshen, New York 10924.
CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 4
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
TWENTIETH: The plaintiffs' class seeks a declaratoryjudgment declaring that a strip
search of a pre-trial detainee undertaken in the absence of a reasonable suspicion
that the detainee subjected to the search is concealing weapons or other contraband
constitutes an unreasonable search and is unconstitutional; an order enjoining de-
fendants from conducting such unconstitutional strip searches; together with com-
pensatory damages for the injuries caused by defendants' unlawful policy and prac-
tice of strip searching pre-trial detainees absent reasonable suspicion. Plaintiffs
are suing on behalf of themselves and all other similarly situated individuals, and
seek to represent a class comprised of all persons who have been or will be placed
in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office and were or presumably will be
strip searched pursuant to the unlawful policy, practice, procedure and custom of
the defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger.
TWENTY-FIRST: The class period commences three years from the date on which this ac-
tion has been filed with the Clerk of the Court for the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York and extends until such a date when the County
of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger are enjoined from, or otherwise cease. enfor-
cing the unconstitutional policy, practice, procedure and custom of conducting strip
searches of pre-trial detainees in the absence of reasonable suspicion.
TWENTY-SECOND: The members of the class are so numerous as to renderjoinder imprac-
ticable. Upon information and belief, there exists thousands of persons who were and
are arrested for misdemeanor or non-criminal offenses in the County of Orange during
the period in question, all of whom are members of the class, by reason of having
been subject to violations of their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights, as well
as such other rights conferred by the Constitution, by the policy, practice, proced-
ure and custom of the defendants mandating uniform strip searches to be conducted of
all pre-trial detainees after being placed in the custody of the Orange County Sher-
iff's office described herein.
TWENTY-THIRD: In addition, upon information and belief, joinder is impracticable be-
cause many members of the class may contain non-English speaking persons of low in-
come and socio-economic status who may likely have great difficulty in pursuing
their personal rights and liberties individually.
TWENTY-FOURTH: The questions oflaw and fact common to the class include that each of
the class members have common rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to
be free from unreasonable and unconstitutional strip searches. and that defendants'
policy, practice, procedure and custom in conducting strip searches of pre-trial de-
tainees in the absence of reasonable suspicion violates those rights.
TWENTY-FIFTH: The named plaintiffs, Anthony Dodge, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Pet-
riello, are adequate representatives of the class. The violation of the law alleged
by the named plaintiffs stems from the same course of conduct by defendants; namely,
that their uniform strip search custom, practice, procedure and policy has violated
and continues to violate the rights of proposed class members. The legal theory un-
der which the named plaintiffs seek relief are the same or similar to that upon
which the class will rely. In addition, the harm suffered by the named plaintiffs
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 5
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
are typical of the harm suffered by the proposed class members.
TWENTY-SIXTH: The named plaintiffs, Anthony Dodge, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Pet-
riello, and each ofthem, have the requisite personal interests in the outcome of
this action and will fairly and adequately protect the in erests of the putative
class. The named plaintiffs are represented by the law firm of Dupee, Dupee & Mon-
roe, P.C. Serving โof counselโ for the law firm of Dupee, Dupee & Monroe, P.C. will
be Mr. Robert N. Isseks, Esq. This law firm, together with Mr. Isseks, have the re-
sources, expertise and experience to prosecute this action. The members of the law
firm for the plaintiffs do not have knowledge of any conflicts among members of the
class or between Dupee, Dupee & Monroe, P.C., Mr. Robert N. Isseks, Esq. and the
members of this proposed class.
TWENTY-SEVENTH: The class action is superior to other available methods for the fair
and efficient adjudication of this controversy because: (i) the prosecution of thou-
sands of separate actions would be inefficient and wasteful of judicial resources;
(ii) the members of the class may be scattered throughout Orange County, the State
of New York and the United States and are not likely to be able to vindicate and en-
force their constitutional and statutory rights unless this action is maintained as
a class action; (iii) the issues raised can be more fairly and efficiently resolved
in the contexts of a single action rather than piece-meal litigation in the context
of separate actions; (iv) the resolution of litigation in a single forum will avoid
the danger and resultant confusion of possible inconsistent determinations; (v) the
prosecution of separate actions would create the risk of inconsistent or varying ad-
judications with respect to individuals pursuing claims against defendants which
would establish incompatible standards of conduct for defendants; (vi) defendants
have acted and will act on grounds applicable to all class members, making final de-
claratory and injunctive relief on behalf of all members necessary and appropriate;
and (vii) questions of law and/or fact common to members of the class especially on
issues of liability predominate over any question, such as that of individual dam-
ages, that will effect individual class members.
FACTS APPLICABLE TO THE CLASS GENERALLY
TWENTY-EIGHTH: The United States Constitution prohibits municipalities and public
officials, such as the County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, from performing
strip searches of pre-trial detainees who have been charged with misdemeanors or
other lesser offenses unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion that the detain-
ee is concealing a weapon, drugs or other contraband.
TWENTY-NINTH: Defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, its of-
ficers, agents, servants and/or employees knew or should have known that they could
not lawfully institute, enforce, condone, affirm or permit the enforcement of a
policy or practice of conducting uniform strip searches of pre-trial detainees in
the absence of reasonable suspicion.
THIRTIETH: The defendant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger and several employees of the Or-
ange County Sheriff's Office have testified in a separate proceeding on June 5,2001
that pre-trial detainees placed in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 6
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
were subjected to an unwritten strip search policy instituted, enforced, ratified
and affirmed by all of the above named defendants regardless of the crime charged or
whether there was reasonable suspicion that the detainee was concealing weapons,
drugs, or other contraband.
THIRTY-FIRST: That the County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger have continued
to implement and enforce this illegal and unconstitutional policy, practice, proced-
ure and custom mandating strip searches of all pre-trial detainees in bad faith and
in blatant disregard of clearly established law.
THIRTY-SECOND: Defendant, County of Orange, shares the responsibility with defend-
ant, Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, for the custody and control of all pre-trial detainees
in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office and participated and affirmed
the enforcement of the Orange County Sheriff's Office strip search policy and/or
knowingly or recklessly failed to prevent the enforcement of a policy that was
plainly unconstitutional.
THIRTY-THIRD: Defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger's policy,
practice, procedure and custom of uniform strip searches of its pre-trial detainees
is not limited to male or female prisoners. Upon information and belief, the County
of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger's policy, practice, procedure and custom man-
dates that all detainees regardless of their gender be routinely strip searched,
wholly absent reasonable suspicion.
THIRTY-FOURTH: Estimated conservatively, upon information and belief, thousands of
persons have been and/or will be arrested and charged with misdemeanor and/or non-
criminal offenses and have been or will be strip searched, absent any inquiry into
or the establishment of reasonable suspicion to justify the search, pursuant to the
County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger's policy, practice, procedure and cus-
tom described above. Upon information and belief, and in every instance, the pre-
trial detainee subjected to the strip search by the Orange County Sheriff's office
personnel had or has already been subject to a search prior to being transported to
the supervision and/or custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office
THIRTY-FIFTH: Pursuant to this uniform strip search policy, and knowing acquiescence
of the same by the County of Orange, each member of the class, including the named
plaintiffs, were the victims of a routine strip search policy, practice, or proced-
ure, conducted prior to or following their arraignment, without inquiry into or es-
tablishment of reasonable suspicion.
THIRTY-SIXTH: As a direct and proximate result of the unlawful strip search conduc-
ted pursuant to this uniform strip search policy, each victim of these unlawful and
unconstitutional strip searches and each member of the class, including these named
plaintiffs, have suffered or will suffer emotional and psychological pain; suffering
and mental anguish.
EXPERIENCES OF NAMED PLAINTIFFS
THIRTY-SEVENTH: Plaintiffs, Anthony Dodge, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Petriello,
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 7
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
and and each of them, after being placed in the custody of the Orange County Sher-
iff's Office, were strip searched pursuant to the unlawful and unconstitutional
policy of the defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff H. Frank Bigger. After being
placed in the custody of the Orange County Sheriff's Office, each of the named
plaintiffs were ordered to remove all of their garments for the visual inspection of
the Orange County Sheriff Office's personnel. During these unlawful and unconstitu-
tional searches in the absence of reasonable suspicion that any of the above named
plaintiffs were in possession of either weapons or contraband, the Orange County
Sheriff's Office personnel were able to view and examine the named plaintiffs'
clothing and personal effects as well as their unclothed bodies. Each of the above
named plaintiffs was also ordered to bend over while completely unclothed and spread
his buttocks to complete the visual inspection and search of his genitalia and anal
cavity.
THIRTY-EIGHTH: There was no reasonable suspicion to believe that any of the above
named plaintiffs were concealing a weapon or other contraband. Indeed, no inquiry
was made of any of the above named plaintiffs, and therefore it could not have given
rise to the requisite reasonable suspicion required by law. Moreover, prior to the
strip search, each of the above named plaintiffs had been frisked for weapons by the
arresting officers prior to being placed in the custody of the Orange County Sher-
iff's Office. Accordingly, the personnel of the Orange County Sheriff's Office knew
or should have known that each of the above named plaintiffs had already been sub-
jected to a search incident to arrest which would have revealed the presence of
weapons or contraband.
THIRTY-NINTH: That as a direct and proximate result of the unlawful and unconstitu-
tional strip searches conducted pursuant to defendants, County of Orange and Sheriff
H. Frank Bigger's policy, practice, procedure and custom, each of the above named
plaintiffs and other similarly situated individuals has suffered and continues to
suffer emotional and psychological pain, humiliation, suffering and mental anguish.
AS AND FOR A FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION PURSUANT TO 42 U.S. ยง1983 (AGAINST ALL DEFEND-
ANTS)
FORTIETH: Plaintiffs repeat, reiterate and reallege with the same force and effect
as iffully set forth herein at length, each and every allegation hereinabove alleged
and set forth in Paragraph โFIRSTโ through โTHIRTY-EIGHTHโ of this complaint.
FORTY-FIRST: By implementing, promulgating, affirming, ratifying and continuing to
enforce and/or effectuate a policy, practice, procedure and custom pursuant to the
named plaintiffs and other members of the plaintiff class who were or will be strip
searched absent the requisite reasonable suspicion, or any other legally-sufficient
justification, each of the above mentioned defendants have deprived and will contin-
ue to deprive each and every plaintiff and members of plaintiff's class of rights,
liberties, freedoms, remedies, privileges and immunities guaranteed to every citizen
of the United States, in violation of 42 U.S.C. ยง1983, and of the rights guarantee
by the Fourth. Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Consti-
tution, and failed to prevent the furtherance and advancement of this unlawful and
ยฉ 2007 Thomson/West. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.) Page 8
(Cite as: 2002 WL 32809555)
unconstitutional policy, practice, procedure or custom.
FORTY-SECOND: At all times hereinafter mentioned, defendants, County of Orange and
Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, and each of them, acted by virtue and color of state law
and in their individual and official capacities and within the scope of their em-
ployment. Said acts by these defendants were beyond the scope of their jurisdiction,
in the absence of legal authority and in willful disregard of the clearly estab-
lished law, and with the specific intent to deprive each of the above named
plaintiffs and those individuals similarly situated, of their constitutional rights,
secured by 42 U.S.C. ยง1983 and by the Fourth, Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the
United States Constitution.
FORTY-THIRD: As a direct and proximate result of the misconduct and abuse of the de-
fendants as set forth above, each and every plaintiff and members of plaintiffs'
class has suffered and continues to suffer emotional and psychological pain, humili-
ation, embarrassment, suffering and mental anguish.
WHEREFORE, plaintiffs demand judgment as follows:
a. A court order certifying this class as a class action pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P.
23(a) and (b) naming the aforementioned plaintiffs as the class representatives;
b. A judgment declaring defendants' policy, practice, procedure and custom mandating
that a strip search be undertaken absent reasonable suspicion that the pre-trial de-
tainee is concealing weapons or other contraband is unconstitutional;
c. An order enjoining defendants' policy, practice, procedure and custom mandating
that a strip search be undertaken in the absence of reasonable suspicion that the
pre-trial detainee is concealing weapons or other contraband;
d. An award of compensatory damages to the named plaintiffs and the members of the
class in an amount to be determined at trial;
e. An award of punitive damages to the named plaintiffs and the members of the class
in an amount to be determined at trial;
f. An award of reasonable attorneys' fees and costs to the named plaintiffs and the
members of the class;
g. Together with such other and further relief as this Court shall find just and
proper.
Anthony DODGE, Peter A. Machado and Joseph Petriello, individually and on behalf of
all others similarly situated, Plaintiff, v. COUNTY OF ORANGE and Sheriff H. Frank
Bigger, in his individual and official capacity, Defendants.
2002 WL 32809555 (S.D.N.Y.)
END OF DOCUMENT

SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
The Parties, by and through their counsel, enter into this Settlement Agreement subject to 
the  approval of the Court, providing for the se ttlement  of  the Plaintif fsโ  claims  against 
Defendants. 
WHEREAS, Plaintiffs Anthony Dodge, Peter Machado, Joseph Petriello, Samuel Rango, 
Jarrod  Mann and Rocco Manniello, filed the a bove-captioned  class action lawsuits against 
Defendants,  the County of Orange and (form er)  Sheriff H. Frank Bigger, alleging that 
Defendants had violated the Const itutional rights of Plaintif fs and others sim ilarly situated by 
NY:773261v8 

subjecting them to Admission Searches upon entry into the Orange County Correctional Facility 
(โOCCFโ). 
WHEREAS, Plaintiffs further alleged that, in violation of law and pursuant to the policy 
of Orange County, all persons such as Plaintif fs and the members of the class they purport to 
represent, who enter the OCCF charged with felony and non-felony offenses are subject to illegal 
Admission Searches absent any particularized  suspicion that they possess weapons or other 
contraband. 
WHEREAS, Defendants have vigorously denied and continue to deny Plaintiffsโ claim s, 
and Defendants deny any wrongdoing or  liability of any kind to Pl aintiffs or to any Class 
Members. 
WHEREAS,  the Parties to  this  Settlement  Agreement  have conducted a thorough 
examination and investigation of the facts and law relating to the matters in this Litigation. 
WHEREAS, Plaintiffs recognize the costs and risks of prosecution of this Litigation, and 
believe that it is in their interest, and the interest of all Class Members, to resolve this Litigation, 
and any and all claim s against Defendants, as  well as all current an d former employees and 
elected officials of the County of Orange. 
WHEREAS, Defendants have concluded that settlement is desirable in order to avoid the 
time, expense, and inherent uncertainties of defending protracted litigation and to resolve finally 
and completely all pending and potential claims of the Plaintiffs and all Class Members relating 
to alleged conduct involved in this Litigation. 
WHEREAS, this Settlement Agreement is the result of substantial settlement negotiations 
between the Parties, and is subject to the Court approval process. 
NY:773261v8  2 

WHEREAS, Plaintiffsโ counsel believe that this Settlement Agreement offers significant 
benefits to Class Mem bers and is fair, reasonable, adequate and  in the best interest of Class 
Members. 
WHEREAS,  this Se ttlement  Agreement  is  made and entered  into  by and among 
Defendants and Plaintiffs, An thony Dodge, Peter Machado, Joseph Petriello, Samuel Rango, 
Jarrod Mann and Rocco Manniello, individually a nd on behalf of a national class of similarly 
situated persons defined as: 
All persons who were detained on non-felony or felony charges 
during the period January 31, 1999 t hrough and including August 
6, 2002 and who were subjected to an adm ission search on their 
initial arrival at the OCCF pursuant to the facilityโs alleged policy 
of subjecting all newly-arrived pre- trial detainees to an admission 
search  without m aking  any individualized assessm ent  of the 
likelihood that they would be ca rrying weapons, drugs or other 
contraband. 
WHEREAS,  the Parties agree that th is  class def inition  comports  with  the 
classes/subclasses certified by the  Court in its January 31, 2005 decision.  Dodge v. County of 
Orange, 226 F.R.D. 177 (S.D.N.Y. 2005).  
NOW, THEREFORE, it is hereby stipulated and agreed, by and between the undersigned 
as follows: 
I.  DEFINITIONS 
As used in this Settlement Agreement, the following terms shall have the meaning set 
forth below. Where appropriate, terms used in the singular shall be deemed to include the plural 
and vice versa. 
A.  Admission Search. โAdmission Searchโ shall mean a visual body search of the 
person of a newly arriving inm ate to the OCCF as part of the initial admissions process.  An 
NY:773261v8  3 

Admission Search requires the inmate to disrobe and expose his/her genitals and other body parts 
to inspection by correctional staff. 
B.  Claim Form. โClaim Formโ shall mean the Pro of of Claim form in substantially 
the same form as Exhibit A attached to this Settlement Agreement. 
C.  Claims List.  โClaims Listโ shall mean a written list of the names of all Class 
Members who submit timely Claim Forms.  
D.  Claims Period. โClaims Periodโ shall mean the time period during which claims 
may be made by Class Members, extending from the Notice Date until a date not later than thirty 
(30) days from when the Summary Notice w as last published in the Tim es Herald Record, 
including weekends and holidays, provided that if  the last day of the Cl aims Period falls on a 
weekend or federal holiday, then the end of th e Claims Period shall be the next following day
